parse.title: List of firsts in the Philippines

text.*:
The following is the list of firsts in the Philippines.

In order to be listed, each feat must be backed up by a third-party reliable source explicitly stating that the feat is the first. Firsts exclusive to a business such as the first branch or property of a particular company in the Philippines is excluded.

Contents

  • 1 Architecture
  • 2 Energy
  • 3 Film
  • 4 Exploration
  • 5 Religion
  • 6 Science and technology
    • 6.1 Medical science
    • 6.2 Nuclear physics
    • 6.3 Space science
  • 7 Sports
    • 7.1 Football
    • 7.2 Olympics
    • 7.3 Others
  • 8 See also
  • 9 Notes
  • 10 References

Architecture[edit]

The following are the first buildings of their type.

  • First mosque: Masjid Sheikh Makhdum in Simunul, Tawi-Tawi. – 1380[1]
  • First LEED Platinum certified building: Zuellig Building – awarded in 2013[2]
  • First steel bridge: Ayala Bridge in Manila – 1908[note 1]

Other

  • First installed elevator: at the Burke Building[4]

Energy[edit]

  • First nuclear power plant: Bataan Nuclear Power Plant[5]

Film[edit]

  • First films screened: Un Homme Au Chapeau (Man with a Hat), Une scene de danse Japonaise (Scene from a Japanese Dance), Les Boxers (The Boxers), and La Place de L’ Opera (The Place L’ Opera) at the Salon de Pertierra in Escolta, Manila – January 1, 1897[6]
  • First films shot: Panorama de Manila (Manila landscape), Fiesta de Quiapo (Quiapo Fiesta), Puwente de España (Bridge of Spain), and Esceñas Callejeras (Street scenes) by Antonio Ramos (also first Filipino motion picture producer) – 1898[6]
  • First hall exclusively for film viewing: Cine Walgrah at No. 60 Calle Santa Rosa in Intramuros, Manila – 1900[6]
  • First Filipino-owned movie theater: Cinematograpo Rizal established by Jose Jimenez along Azcarraga street in Manila – 1903[6]

Exploration[edit]

  • First Filipino to reach the peak of Mount Everest: Dale Abenojar – May 15, 2006[note 2]
  • First Filipino to reach the North Pole: Ramon Ilusorio – 1996[9]

Religion[edit]

  • First Filipino Catholic cardinal: Rufino Santos – by Pope John XXIII in 1960[10]
  • First Filipino Catholic saint: Lorenzo Ruiz – canonized by Pope Benedict XVI on October 21, 2012.[11]

Science and technology[edit]

The PRR-1, the first nuclear reactor in the Philippines.

Medical science[edit]

  • First kidney transplant: Rainier Lagman by a 12-man medical team led by Dr. Jorge Garcia at the Makati Medical Center – May 28, 1994[12]

Nuclear physics[edit]

  • First nuclear reactor: Philippine Research Reactor-1[13] – first criticality in 1963[14]

Space science[edit]

  • First satellites:
    • First satellite owned by a Filipino entity: Agila 1/Mabuhay – acquired as Palapa B2-P by Mabuhay Satellite Corporation from PT Pasifik Satelit Nusantara in 1996
    • First Filipino satellite launched to space: Agila 2 – launched in 1997
    • First satellite designed and built by Filipinos / microsatellite: Diwata-1 – launched and deployed in 2016

Sports[edit]

Teófilo Yldefonso, the first athlete to win a medal for the Philippines at the Olympics.

Football[edit]

  • First official football game: Match at the opening of the Philippine Assembly – October 15, 1907[note 3]
  • First football tournament: 1913 Far Eastern Championship Games (Also first in Asia)[16]

Olympics[edit]

  • First competitor for the Philippines in the Olympics: David Nepomuceno (athletics) – 1924 Summer Olympics in Paris[17]
  • First Filipino Olympic medalist: Teofilo Yldefonso (swimming) – Bronze medalist; Men's 200 meter breaststroke at the 1928 Summer Olympics in Amsterdam[18]
  • First Filipino Olympic silver medallist: Anthony Villanueva (boxing) – Men's featherweight at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Tokyo[18]
  • First Filipino Olympic gold medallist: Arianne Cerdeña (bowling) – 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul[note 4]
  • First Filipino Winter Olympians: Juan Cipriano and Ben Nanasca (alpine skiing) – 1972 Winter Olympics in Sapporo[20]

Others[edit]

  • First Filipino Woman Grand Master: Janelle Mae Frayna – September 2016[21][note 5]

See also[edit]

  • List of Philippine presidential firsts
  • List of records of the Philippines

Notes[edit]

  1. ^ First built in 1872 as a wooden bridge. Reconstructed as a steel bridge in 1908.[3]
  2. ^ Abenojar was the first Filipino to reach Mt. Everest's peak who climbed from Tibet, China, two days earlier than Heracleo Oracion of the First Philippine Mount Everest Expedition (FPMME) who was earlier reported to have done the feat. Oracion is joined by fellow Filipinos Erwin Emata, and Romeo Garduce. The FPMME climbed from the Nepal side of the mountain.[7] A month earlier, Ronuel Aquino claimed to have climbed the mountain first but Nepalese authorities denied the claim. It was reported that Aquino climbed Island Peak instead.[8]
  3. ^ It was not specified in the source which clubs or teams participated in the match but the trophy of the tournament was won by Sandow football team which became a club in 1909.[15]
  4. ^ Bowling was just a demonstration sport at the 1988 Summer Olympics therefore the medal is not credited to the overall medal tally for the Philippines. There is yet to be a competitor for the Philippines to win a gold medal in a regular sport in the Olympics.[19]
  5. ^ Became woman grand master in 2016, title confirmed by FIDE in March 2017.[22]

References[edit]

The Zuellig Building is the first development in the Philippines, and among the first in Asia, to earn the highest level [Platinum] in the LEED rating system for “green” architecture, sustainable construction methodologies and resource-efficient building operations. 
  3. ^ "Ayala Bridge completely closed March 21 to April 2". CNN Philippines. 23 July 2015. Retrieved 14 December 2016. Built in 1872, the Ayala Bridge was initially made of wood but was reconstructed in steel in 1908. It was the first steel bridge in the Philippines.

  8. ^ "Filipino climber claims reaching Mt. Everest first". GMA News. GMANews.TV. 28 April 2016. Retrieved 14 December 2016. 
  9. ^ Viernes, Miles (15 May 2015). "Filipina joins expedition to the North Pole". Rappler. Retrieved 30 May 2018.

  15. ^ Alcarazen, Paulo (9 April 2011). "The first & future Azkals". The Philippine Star. Retrieved 14 December 2016. 
  16. ^ Siasat, JM (17 June 2014). "Remembering the Philippines as a football nation". Rappler. Retrieved 14 December 2016. 
  17. ^ Plaza, Gerry (7 August 2016). "First Pinoy Olympians were the most bemedalled". ABS-CBN Sports. Retrieved 30 May 2018.
